title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Book club  - Introduction to Statistical Learning 2nd Ed.  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
The second version of ISLR is out! Many of us have read the popular first edition of the book. This book club will focus on the sections that are new, so it is highly recommended that you have read the first version of the book or at least have a solid background in the material that it covers.

The following sections will be covered:
* Deep learning
* Survival analysis
* Multiple testing
* Naive Bayes and generalized linear models
* Bayesian additive regression trees
* Matrix completion

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Monday between 4:00 and 5:00 PM PST for seven weeks (Sept 13 to Oct 25th).

Book: Title: An Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R, 2nd Ed.
Dead Tree: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1071614177/
PDF: https://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/ISLRv2_website.pdf

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

title: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group: Tidy Thursday: Remote Workshop  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group
description:
Come join us for this next Tidy Thursday session.

Tidy Tuesdays are weekly R projects on 'tidying' data, associated (but not exclusive!) to the 'tidyverse': ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr and friends.

You can find out more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We will meet (on Thursday!), find the most recent data set and 'tidy' it up together.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
This week we have: "Top 100 Billboard"

https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2021/2021-09-14

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This session will be beginner-friendly, hands-on, and potentially pair programming driven.

Learning outcomes: Data Preparation, Data Munging, Tidy Data, Tidyverse

It would be helpful for attendees to have the following already installed, but if you run into trouble we can help on the day.

* R: https://www.r-project.org/
* R Studio desktop: https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/
* Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org/

These are all free tools, and install will take roughly 20-40 min depending on hardware and internet speeds.

Our previous work is available here:
https://github.com/CaRdiffR/tidy_thursdays

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: Uncertainty visualization with tidybayes and ggdist  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
Details
When communicating statistical results, we must consider carefully how to communicate uncertainty in ways that people can actually use to make informed decisions. I will describe some useful strategies, tools, and techniques for doing so, based on my (and others') research and my own practice. I will also showcase recent updates to the tidybayes and ggdist R packages designed to make it easy to quickly create a variety of custom uncertainty visualizations from Bayesian models.

About the speaker:
Dr Matthew Kay is an Assistant Professor in CS and Communication at Northwestern, previously an Assistant Professor at UMSI. His research interest includes communicating uncertainty, usable statistics, and personal informatics, in the areas of human–computer interaction and information visualization. Matthew is the author of the tidybayes and ggdist R packages for uncertainty visualization.

About the event:
This event is part of Bayes@Lund workshop series, co-organized with Skåne R User Group.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Automated Data Labeling with Machine Learning  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/automated-data-labeling-with-machine-learning

Labeling training data is the one step in the data pipeline that has resisted automation. It’s time to change that.

The significant issues with hand labeling include the introduction of bias (and hand labels are neither interpretable nor explainable), the prohibitive costs (both financial costs and the time of subject matter experts), and the fact that there is no such thing as gold labels (even the most well-known hand labeled datasets have label error rates of at least 5%!).

Shayan Mohanty, CEO of Watchful, joins Hugo Bowne-Anderson, Head of Data Science Evangelism at Coiled, to discuss why hand labeling, a fundamental part of human-mediated machine intelligence, is naive, dangerous, and expensive. He will share the ever-growing world of alternatives, which includes semi-supervised learning, weak supervision, and active learning. Hand labeling in the age of these other technologies is akin to scribes hand-copying books post-Gutenberg.

All attendees will:

-Learn about techniques and approaches to scale data annotation
-Receive a Jupyter Notebook that will guide the attendee through some of the concepts discussed
-Receive a one-page summary of the key-concepts covered after the webinar

Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/automated-data-labeling-with-machine-learning

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] AI Inference Workloads: Solving Challenges Beyond Training Models  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/ai-inference-workloads-solving-challenges-beyond-training-models

In recent years, enterprise AI initiatives have made great strides in solving the challenges of training massive, distributed computational models. Data wrangling, experimentation management, GPU resource allocation…these challenges have spawned an ever-growing market of new tools and considerable investment. But despite all this, the ability to productize AI is still stunted in most enterprises.

In our survey of more than 200 data scientists and MLOps/IT experts, a majority of AI/ML models still aren’t making it to production. AI/ML teams are now under pressure to optimize and manage AI inference workloads in production and deliver a return on investment.

In this webinar, we will walk through the distinct characteristics of each stage in the ML lifecycle and their computational requirements. We’ll discuss solutions to improve throughput and reduce latency, and finally, we’ll show how one organization built an efficient inference platform on top of Kubernetes to support their scaling AI initiatives.

“Rapid AI development is what this is all about for us. What Run:AI helps us do is to move from a company doing pure research, to a company with results in production.”

Siddharth Sharma, Sr. Research Engineer, Wayve

Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/ai-inference-workloads-solving-challenges-beyond-training-models

description:

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Interpreting Datasets for Wildfire Risks in the American West  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/interpreting-datasets-for-wildfire-risks-in-the-american-west

Utilities have long spent considerable time, attention, and treasure on vegetation management, often yielding disappointing or catastrophic results.

California utilities, for example, have been responsible for several deadly and costly fire events, despite spending more than 1B dollars per year on utility vegetation management.

While this issue has received widespread public and utility industry consideration, very few approaches are available that are scientifically accurate, up-to-date, and scalable.

This webinar shows how OmniSci enables organizations to orient big geospatial data toward advanced vegetation management and efficient risk mitigation.

Specifically, we’ll explore the cross-section of tree health & mortality, electrical transmission lines, weather, and the probability of four and eight-foot flames across California.

Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/interpreting-datasets-for-wildfire-risks-in-the-american-west

title: Inland Northwest R User Group (INRUG): Changing the display of statistically significant correlation coefficients  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Speakers: Vivek Patil and Fred Franken

Non-truncated title of talk: Visualization of statistically significant correlation coefficients from a correlation matrix: a call for a change in practice

Abstract: This talk will discuss a forthcoming article in the Journal of Marketing Analytics on the visualization of correlation matrices. The article discusses two studies that provide evidence that commonly used formats for displaying statistical significance, namely, the use of different number of asterisks and the use of absolute values, are inefficient. Using lessons drawn from the literature on visual perception, we propose the use of variations in hue and intensity of numbers to reduce the amount of time and effort taken to glean information from correlation matrices. We also create and describe a web-based engine, which is a shiny app, that can be used to implement these modified approaches to display correlation matrices.

Speaker Profiles: Vivek H. Patil, Ph.D., is a Professor of Marketing at Gonzaga University. Fred Franken, Ph.D., has over 15 years of experience in data analysis. His background includes work at the NIH, in the private sector, and in numerous academic research laboratories, including Oregon Health and Science University, where he earned his PhD in Behavioral Neuroscience in 2011. He currently works as a quantitative analyst at U.S. Bank where he is responsible for the validation of a diverse portfolio of models used for Anti-Money Laundering and Sanctions screening.

title: Cleveland R User Group: Ryan Honomichl: Linking patient-reported outcomes measures with PROsetta  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) are an increasingly important topic in healthcare that allows clinicians and researchers to hear from patients directly. One issue that emerges from this is the need to connect or "crosswalk" scores across different measures on the same or similar constructs (e.g., depressive symptoms). Recently the PROsetta package was created based on the work of Choi et al. (2014) to achieve this with diverse populations and subgroups. We will discuss the issue of cross-walking and how this package achieves this with examples.

Choi, S. W., Schalet, B., Cook, K. F., & Cella, D. (2014). Establishing a common metric for depressive symptoms: linking the BDI-II, CES-D, and PHQ-9 to PROMIS depression. Psychological assessment, 26(2), 513.

Ryan Honomichl is a Quantitative Research Associate from Happify
Health, where he uses PROMs to assess mental health and well-being in Happify users. He is a long term and passionate R user.

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: R packages for using Stan  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our September Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

One of the most powerful ways to use R is to recognize when it is not the best tool for the job, but instead use it to interface with software better suited to a particular job. One tool that is very powerful for doing Bayesian analysis is Stan. While some Bayesian MCMC can be done in R, it is much more efficient to have Stan do the heavy computations, but use R to prepare the data and explore the results. This presentation will introduce some of the packages available that interface between R and Stan to help harness the power of both.

Greg Snow was first introduced to an early port of the S language over 30 years ago (shortly after dropping out of high school) and has been working with first S and then R ever since (including a year working for MathSoft who sold S-Plus). Somewhere along the line Greg's wife pointed out that being a professional student does not pay well and made him finish his Ph.D. (biostatistics) and get a "real" job. Greg has worked at Intermountain Healthcare for the last 18 years helping researchers with everything from study design, data analysis, data de-identification, to better presentation of results (but no touching patients -- good for him and the patients). Greg is also an adjunct professor at both BYU and the U of U (both ID cards reside in the same wallet and have not yet burst into flames at their proximity).

title: Oslo useR! Group: Extending the Functionalities of {metafor}  [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
[Info]
This event is a follow-up from the 26 August 2021 Oslo useR! event. You can find the recording of August event here: https://youtu.be/IkduL5iRdqo

[Talks]

1)

Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effect Sizes: Robust Variance Estimation with {clubSandwich} (James Pustejovsky)

Large meta-analyses often involve dependent effect sizes, but where the exact form of the dependence is unknown. Meta-analysis with robust variance estimation handles this problem through specification of a working model for the dependence, which need not be correct. However, the two currently available working models are limited to each describing a single type of dependence. James will demonstrate a workflow for implementing an expanded set of working models by combining the metafor and clubSandwich R packages. A pre-print is available at https://osf.io/preprints/metaarxiv/vyfcj/.

2)

Introduction to Meta-Analytic Structural Equational Modeling with {metaSEM} (Diego G. Campos)

We often formulate models to understand how our data is connected. However, it is difficult to assess whether our model is a good representation of the data or the generalizability of our model to other contexts. With {metaSEM}, researchers can combine data from several primary studies to investigate the generalizability of a model. In this talk, we will show you the steps to perform a meta-analytic structural equational modelling (MASEM) with the {metaSEM} package.

3)

Calculating the Statistical Power of Studies Included in a Meta-Analysis Using {metameta} (Daniel Quintana)

Several methods exist for assessing study quality in meta-analysis, but these are typically discipline specific. One approach used across disciplines to assess the evidential value of an individual study is to calculate its statistical power, which can identify the range of effect sizes that can be reliably detected. Studies that cannot detect realistic effect sizes are unlikely to be replicated. A meta-analysis with mostly studies not capable of reliably detecting realistic effects would therefore have less credibility. This talk describes {metameta}, an R package that can effortlessly calculate and visualise the statistical power of studies included in a meta-analysis.

4)

Meta-Analysis of Nonparametric Models with {metagam} (Øystein Sørensen)

"Most meta-analytic tools have focused on parametric statistical models, and software for meta-analyzing nonparametric and semiparametric models like generalized additive models (GAMs) have not been developed. The metagam package attempts to fill this gap: It provides functionality for removing individual participant data from GAM objects such that they can be analyzed in a common location, as well as various tools for visualization and statistical analysis."

[Speakers]

James Pustejovsky is a statistician and Associate Professor in the School of Education at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. His research involves developing statistical methods for problems in social science research, with a focus on meta-analysis methods. He completed his PhD in statistics from Northwestern University in 2013. His homepage is https://www.jepusto.com/

Diego G. Campos is a doctoral research fellow at the Centre for Educational Measurement at the University of Oslo. His research covers meta-analysis, structural equational models, and multilevel analysis. Diego is currently working on the use of IPD meta-analysis for the synthesis of complex survey data.

Daniel Quintana (@dsquintana) is a Senior Researcher in the Department of Psychology at the University of Oslo and co-host of the research methodology podcast "Everything Hertz".

Øystein Sørensen is an Associate Professor in Statistics at the Department of Psychology, University of Oslo. He works on both applied data analysis projects as well as the development of new statistical tools and is the author of four R packages. He received his Ph.D. from the UiO in 2014. His homepage is https://osorensen.rbind.io/

title: Portland R User Group: aggregate: meet, greet, learn, collaborate  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for the 44th R aggRegate meetup on Zoom! We welcome current or aspiring R users who have any level of experience with the R programming language.

Our goal is to exchange knowledge, learn new skills, help each other troubleshoot coding problems, and meet new fellow R users.

No topic is off limits, and you may attend even if you don’t feel that you have anything to share. Come learn with us!

Details:

When: September 21 @ 6:30 PM

Where: The meeting will take place on Zoom. Zoom link is provided when you RSVP.

Agenda:

• No talk this month.

• Brief intro/R project or problem: We'll take turns talking about an R project we're working on, a data/data-science problem, or something we want to learn, etc.

• Next, anyone can share some code they've been working on and want help with / want feedback on. Make sure to have this ready before the meeting.

• Before arriving, use the pdxrlang/aggregate GitHub repository to discuss ideas for things to work on at aggregate - https://github.com/pdxrlang/aggregate/issues

Please note that this event, like all PDX R events, adheres to the PDX R Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code-of-conduct.html We are dedicated to a safe learning environment to all.

If you have any trouble message Marley in the meetup app, or on Twitter at @pdxrlang

title: R Users Group, Gainesville, FL: Data Wrangling with Tidyverse  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For this meetup we'll be referencing Claire Carroll's fantastic post (https://blog.getdbt.com/modeling-subscription-revenue/) on modeling subscription revenue in DBT. We'll be converting the data transformation process from DBT to R. While it's not required, we suggest that you read the post before the meetup to get an understanding of the data used and the transformation process. Prior knowledge of DBT or SQL is not necessary.

For those that are adventurous how about you try this exercise and share your code with us? There will be time at the end of the presentation for code sharing. There are numerous ways to execute this transformation and it'll be interesting to see how different minds approach it.

The data can be found at https://github.com/dbt-labs/mrr-playbook . Additionally, here's an RScript (https://github.com/RusersGNV/r-users-meetup-gnv/blob/main/2021-09-21/starter.R) for getting started.

RSVP to get the Zoom link :)

We're excited to (virtually) see you all!

Kind regards
Geraldine, Laurence, and Ryan

title: LondonR: Data Science Meet Up, Big Data LDN: Register via Tito for free ticket, United Kingdom, Europe
description:
We're hosting a Data Science meet up at this year's Big Data LDN event on Wednesday 22nd September, 6-8pm (BST) with pizza and drinks!

We've invited guest speakers from The Gym Group and The Bank of England to discuss their analytics use cases, as well as Mango's Data Scientist Team Lead, Kapil Patel, who'll be covering best practice methodologies to enable long-lived business results.

Places are limited due to room capacity so don't delay - register via the Tito link below.

Register here for a ticket: https://ti.to/big-data-ldn/mango-data-science-meet-up?source=meetup

title: R-Ladies Bariloche: GRUPO 2. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versión traducida al español de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes más!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ ¡Está muy bueno!

• Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 días para avanzar con la lectura y comprensión del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro será guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

• En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo número 3 “visualización de datos” (¡Qué bueno, empezamos con gráficos con ggplot2 ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reunión con el capítulo previamente leído y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducción del libro aún: adelante, es corta, y les dará un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reunión de organización vimos un panorama de la introducción.

• En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. ¡ATENCIÓN! ¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÁS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO 2, DE MIÉRCOLES DE 14 A 16.

• ¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sólo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrónico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

• Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aún no se sumaron, van a recibir más adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que será nuestra principal vía de comunicación. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escríbannos y les damos una orientación rápida.

• Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capítulo número 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo [masked]. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

• A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionará. Por ejemplo, sorteará o decidirá quién guiará el siguiente capítulo, si verán un capítulo, medio capítulo o dos capítulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarán lo que se vió en el capítulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir información en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el código de conducta que encontrarán en la página.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos básicos de R.

¡ATENCIÓN! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reunión se enviará unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estén alertas al correo.

title: R-Ladies Bariloche: Buenas prácticas para el flujo de trabajo en R  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Nuevo meetup de R-ladies Bariloche! ¡No te lo pierdas! ¡Vamos a trabajar en las buenas prácticas para el flujo de trabajo en R!

En esta oportunidad Gabriel Tovar nos invita a pensar que como científicos, hacemos preguntas al mundo a través de hipótesis y experimentos y el mundo nos responde con datos. Es parte del trabajo como científico traducir esos datos para que otras personas los comprendan. Gabriel nos dice: si los datos son el lenguaje de la ciencia, entonces R es la herramienta para traducir esos datos. En este meetup sobre las “Buenas prácticas para el flujo de trabajo en R” hablaremos de consideraciones a tener al momento de trabajar y programar en R. Así como aprendimos las normas de seguridad antes de entrar a un laboratorio, o las normas de conducta antes de entrar a una biblioteca, programar códigos tiene algunas normas que nos harán la vida más fácil al momento de escribir códigos o un script. Y así traducir esos datos científicos para poder comunicarlos efectivamente en una publicación académica.

El taller se realizará el viernes 10 de septiembre de 15:00 a 17 hs, en forma virtual ¡Inscribite! No te olvides de leer y aceptar el código de conducta

¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sólo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrónico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos:
1- Poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet)

2- Tener conocimientos elementales de R, qué es un script, cómo llamar paquetes, setear el directorio de trabajo y cargar un archivo de datos.

¡ATENCIÓN! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reunión se enviará unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que estén alertas al correo.
Los datos que utilicemos y el script estarán disponibles una vez finalizada la reunión en el repositorio de github.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: I Made an Entire E-Commerce Platform on Shiny  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
We have repeat R Conference Speaker Jacqueline Nolis speaking at this year's pre-conference Meetup.

The R Conference is now completely virtual with workshops on September 1st and the conference September 9-10. For tickets and more information visit https://rstats.ai/nyr/.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
E-commerce has many components that must be securely handled–managing a user's shopping cart, checking out and taking payment, and fulfilling orders. I am excited to say that I've successfully created an e-commerce platform entirely in a single Shiny app for my side project: {ggirl}. Using the experimental {brochure} package by Colin Fay I was able to make a complex Shiny web service that lets R users order physical postcards of ggplots. I integrated Stripe for payments and used webhooks to know when to fulfill orders. I even used {httr} to make API calls to order the physical products from suppliers after the customer payments are received. In this talk I'll go through the architecture I devised and how you can make an ecommerce platform yourself!

About Jacqueline:
Dr. Jacqueline Nolis is a data science leader with over 15 years of experience in managing data science teams and projects at companies ranging from DSW to Airbnb. She currently is the Head of Data Science at Saturn Cloud where she helps design products for data scientists. Jacqueline has a PhD in Industrial Engineering and coauthored the book Build a Career in Data Science. For fun she likes to use data science for humor—like using deep learning to generate offensive license plates.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Buenos Aires: Cómo empezaR: desde las Ciencias Sociales hacia las Ciencias de Datos  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Si venís de las Ciencias Sociales y no sabés como empezar en el mundo de la ciencia de datos este meetup es para vos! Desde el Núcleo de Innovación Social (NIS) y RLadies Buenos Aires les traemos esta charla con 4 expositorxs egresadxs de carreras vinculadas a las Ciencias Sociales que trabajan en ciencia de datos.

Cada unx contará su experiencia de primera mano sobre cómo arrancaron en este tipo de roles, qué trabas tuvieron, qué dificultades enfrentaron, y qué herramientas consideran que les sumaron y que pueden servirle a unx egresadx que quiera inciarse en mundo de la ciencia de datos.

Exponen:
- Andrea Gómez Vargas (@me_andre) - Socióloga
- Pedro Orden (@pedroorden) - Sociólogo, investigador y científico de datos.
- Ramiro Fernández (@ramaol) - Sociólogo y científico de datos
- María Cristina Nanton (@bynans1) - Comunicadora social y analista de datos

Coordina:
Betsy Cohen (@betsy_ar) - Socióloga

***IMPORTANTE***
Para participar poné "Asistiré" en este evento y asegurate de tener también instalado Zoom en tu computadora (https://zoom.us/download).

Por razones de seguridad no compartiremos el link para ingresar a Zoom de manera pública. El mismo dia del evento a las 17:30 hs. vamos a mandar un mail a través de Meetup a todas las personas que confirmaron asistencia con el link para que puedas unirte a la videollamada.

title: Birmingham R User Group (R Programming Language): [Online] September BirminghamR Meetup  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: Birmingham R User Group (R Programming Language)
description:
For our September meetup we will have a talk by Andrew Collier (https://datawookie.dev/). The meetup will be online, hopefully for the last time (link to be added).

Title: {emayili} - A package for sending tidy emails from R

Abstract: {emayili} is a library for easily sending emails from R. It has minimal dependencies and intuitive syntax. I'll talk a little about email in general, what motivated me to build {emayili} and what I have learned along the way.

title: Vienna<-R: Tunis-R / ViennaR: gganimate R Package: Animating ggplot2  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
We are happy to share some info on the start of the #OnePackagePerMeetup series at **Tunis R User Group**.
They will be hosting amazing guests!
For the next few months focus will be on some of the powerful data visualization packages that are available in the programming language R.

The first online workshop will cover the gganimate R package: animating ggplot2's grammar of graphics (https://github.com/thomasp85/gganimate) with Mitchell O'Hara-Wild.

➡️ Mitchell O'Hara-Wild (https://www.mitchelloharawild.com/) is a data science developer, consultant, educator, and hobbyist. He is the lead developer of many R packages, including the tidy time series forecasting package 'fable' (https://fable.tidyverts.org/), and R Markdown CV writing package 'vitae' (https://github.com/mitchelloharawild/vitae). Mitchell also teaches data analysis skills and undertakes research at Monash University in Australia. Data also finds its way into his hobbies, to help manage the veggie patch, chickens, bees and more.

➡️ Place: Zoom
➡️ Date/Time: Thursday, September 23, 2021 from 7PM to 9PM Tunisian time (GMT +1) == 08:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. VIENNA [CEST] time

It is recommended you to have a look at the convenient world clock website https://lnkd.in/gUAZxQM if you're struggling to find the right time according to your time zone.

➡️ About the workshop:
Animation is a powerful storytelling tool for your data analysis that bridges the gap between static and interactive visualisations to provide a guided exploration of the data. The gganimate package extends the widely used and much loved ggplot2 package, and introduces a grammar for animation that integrates seamlessly with the grammar of graphics. This workshop will guide you through the world of animated data visualisation - we'll discuss when and why animation should be used, and how to extend your plots with animation. title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: September meetup: A twitter tweet symphony about #IchBinHanna   [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Twitter traffic is highly fascinating - and complex to look at, too. While tweets and their time stamps are certainly interesting in themselves, much more information is potentially available (with the right API access, that is). Meta-information on those who tweeted, retweeted, and liked, their networks and history... Just think of all the things to find out about!

For our September meetup, we will explore the structure of these files and think of ways to manage, analyze and visualize such data. We will use tweets on #IchBinHanna, a recent discussion about the job situation of acedemic staff in Germany (which is bitter) which made it's way into a Bundestag hearing (which is sweet).

Whether you work in academia yourself or not, whether you have explored the twitter API already or not, feel free to join and use this as yet another opportunity to learn about R and from each other. As always, everyone is welcome to join the conversation, ask questions and share their ideas and experiences, no matter their background or skill level.

title: R-Ladies Philly: Causal Inference with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Across public health, medicine, and social and behavioral sciences, researchers aim to answer causal questions. However, inferences about causation are challenging and require several assumptions to draw unbiased causal effects from observational data. This workshop discusses the difference between association and causation and introduces various methods to infer causal effects with observational data. We will then study R packages that implement propensity score techniques to estimate an average treatment effect – such as matching, subclassification, and inverse probability weighting. The workshop also provides several implementation options depending on the data type and the target causal effects of interest.

About our speaker:

Youjin Lee is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Biostatistics at the Brown School of Public Health. Her research focuses on developing causal inference methods with complex data where standard assumptions are often violated. She published R packages for causal inference with social network data and multilevel settings. Originally from South Korea, Youjin received her Ph.D. in Biostatistics from Johns Hopkin University. Before joining Brown University, she did her postdoctoral training at the University of Pennsylvania.

Note from organizers:

We're excited to see so much enthusiasm for this topic! Please note that the zoom room is capped at 100 participants - if you would like to attend, please make sure to be on time. We will be recording the meetup, so if you aren't able to attend the live webinar, we will share the recoding on our YouTube channel after the session.

Data Storytelling with Effective Data Visualization Techniques

Abstract:
If a data scientist spends 80% of their time cleaning the data and 20% of their time performing analysis, where is the allocated time for the effective communication of your results? Storytelling is an integral part of conveying your findings and data visualization is a key tool for the job. In this session we will discuss data visualization guidelines, tips and tricks as well as available resources to help you tell your story with data.

title: R-Ladies Miami: [Webinar] AI Inference Workloads: Solving Challenges Beyond Training Models, United States, US/Canada
description:
Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/ai-inference-workloads-solving-challenges-beyond-training-models

In recent years, enterprise AI initiatives have made great strides in solving the challenges of training massive, distributed computational models. Data wrangling, experimentation management, GPU resource allocation…these challenges have spawned an ever-growing market of new tools and considerable investment. But despite all this, the ability to productize AI is still stunted in most enterprises.

In our survey of more than 200 data scientists and MLOps/IT experts, a majority of AI/ML models still aren’t making it to production. AI/ML teams are now under pressure to optimize and manage AI inference workloads in production and deliver a return on investment.

In this webinar, we will walk through the distinct characteristics of each stage in the ML lifecycle and their computational requirements. We’ll discuss solutions to improve throughput and reduce latency, and finally, we’ll show how one organization built an efficient inference platform on top of Kubernetes to support their scaling AI initiatives.

“Rapid AI development is what this is all about for us. What Run:AI helps us do is to move from a company doing pure research, to a company with results in production.”

Siddharth Sharma, Sr. Research Engineer, Wayve

Register here: https://info.datascience.salon/ai-inference-workloads-solving-challenges-beyond-training-models

title: R-Ladies Melbourne: Anomalies! You can’t escape them  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
Hi Everyone!

This month we are excited to host Sevvandi Kandanaarachchi, who will be giving a seminar on data anomaly detection!

Why are anomalies important? Because they tell us a different story from the norm. An anomaly or an event might signify a failing heart rate of a patient, a fraudulent credit card activity, or an early indication of a tsunami. As such, it is extremely important to detect anomalies or anomalous events.

In this talk, we will give an introduction to anomaly detection. Anomalies are rare events. As a result, standard accuracy measures do not apply. But then, how do we evaluate an Anomaly Detection (AD) method? If we want to compare two or more AD methods, what kind of simple tests can we do? What are the data repositories that are available for AD?

We will also discuss an ensemble method for AD. Constructing an AD ensemble is challenging because the class labels are not known. We will look at an unusual ally from psychometrics – Item Response Theory – to help us in this construction.

Sevvandi is an applied mathematician at RMIT Mathematics working in data science and analytics. She uses statistics, mathematics and machine learning for her research. Her main research interest is anomaly and event detection. Examples of anomalies include finding alien life on a planet far, far away, or closer to home, a stock market crash. She also likes working on real world problems, especially ones that are motivated by industry.

This will be an online event. Please connect to the zoom session at 5:30pm on September 16th.

We look forward to seeing everyone at the seminar!

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Create colourful, publication-ready tables with {gt} & {gtsummary}  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
In this workshop, we'll explore the {gt} package and create beautiful, colourful tables together. The name gt stands for "grammar of tables" because its approach is similar to that of ggplot: setting up an underlying structure which allows users to build up tables layer by layer.

We'll start by creating summary tables with our other favourite (collection of) packages - the tidyverse. Then, we'll make these tables look pretty with {gt} - add and polish the descriptions, change column widths, add a splash or two of colour. We'll also cover adding subgroups, summaries such as averages, and spanners to group columns together.

Finally, we'll take a look at the {gtsummary} package to create custom tables of descriptive statistics and learn how to export our beautiful tables in a variety of different formats.

---
It's important to us to ensure that R-Ladies Freiburg events are a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments/ questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

Esto incluye los siguientes capítulos:
Capítulo 4 - Flujo de trabajo: Conocimientos básicos.
Capítulo 5 - Transformación de datos
Capítulo 6 - Flujo de trabajo: Scripts
Capítulo 8 - Flujo de trabajo: Proyectos

title: R-Ladies Johannesburg: treeheatr and pmlbr: visualizing decision trees on benchmark datasets  [Virtual] , South Africa, Africa
description:
The presentation of the decision tree with data represented as a heatmap is a new visualization that uncovers the tree's performance, the data's correlation structure, and the importance of each feature in predicting the outcome. Implemented in an easily installed package with a detailed vignette, treeheatr can be a useful teaching tool to enhance students’ understanding of a simple decision tree model before diving into more complex tree-based machine learning methods. We will apply decision tree models and visualize them on multiple benchmark machine learning datasets in pmlbr.

About our speaker:
Trang Le is a postdoctoral fellow with Jason Moore at the Computational Genetics Lab, University of Pennsylvania. She enjoys developing machine learning methods for rigorous analyses of a wide array of biomedical data. Most recently, her work focuses on investigating the long-term effect of neurological conditions in COVID-19 patients. She’s the author and maintainer of multiple R packages.

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: September 2021: lessons learned on emailing with R, and COVID-19 dashboards  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
description:
Hi everyone,

The first session of 2021/22 will be on September 15th, join us from 5.30pm online! As usual, the meeting is open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are especially welcome.

In order to join us, please register with MeetUp (https://www.meetup.com/EdinbR/).

We've set up a chat group for EdinbR, come and catch up with the community on Matrix (https://matrix.to/#/#edinbr:matrix.org). **The event will be live-streamed from there**. We will also be running a stream to YouTube, if you are unable to join us on Matrix.

Our speakers are Andrew Collier and Joe Adams.

* **Andrew Collier** (https://twitter.com/datawookie) is a former physicist who now runs a data science consultancy, Fathom Data. He spends an inordinate amount of time working in R and Python, but also likes to dabble in other technologies. Also likes to run.

* **Joe Adams** currently leads a team of 2 Statisticians (including himself) focussed on making official statistics at National Records of Scotland more impactful and accessible. He has worked in various analytical roles at Scottish Government, NHS Scotland, and PricewaterhouseCoopers.

---

## `emayili` - A tidy package for sending emails from R

### Andrew Collier

`emayili` (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/emayili/) is a library for easily sending emails from R. It has minimal dependencies and intuitive syntax. I'll talk a little about email in general, what motivated me to build `emayili` and what I have learned along the way.

---

## How the Scottish Government used R to build a COVID-19 dashboard

### Joe Adams

The Scottish Government has used a range of evidence to inform decisions about COVID-19. Find out how this evidence was gathered into a single public facing dashboard (https://data.gov.scot/coronavirus-covid-19/) to build transparency and public engagement. You will hear about specific technical decisions, our design process, and the lessons we learnt.

---

See you there!

/federico

description:
We have the following topics for the next meeting:

Regular Expressions! Not a new topic, but everyone needs them from time to time and many of us dread them a bit. We want to brainstorm together on how to use them in R.
https://www.regular-expressions.info/

Postponed from August: Robert will give us a short introduction to the new modularisation features for Shiny apps:
https://shiny.rstudio.com/articles/modules.html

Short presentation on current poll results for the 2021 federal election in Germany. This will be our last view on the polls before the election.
https://github.com/hwborchers/Umfragen

We plan to have an event where we will compare different deep learning approaches (maybe even implemented in different programming languages) to analyze the same data set. At first, we need to find a suitable data set (not too big, not too small). Feel free to post suggestions so that we can discuss what might be good data for this.

NEWS:
The 2nd Edition of the book "An Introduction to Statistical Learning - with Applications in R" has appeared! It contains new chapters (e.g., on Deep Learning) and has 30% more pages. A free PDF file is available.

See you online on September 14th!
Oliver

Suggestions of topics would be welcome. 'Lightning Talks' of 7-10 minutes and only very few (or no) slides are a good possibility, e.g. pointing out a package you would like to recommend or learn more about.

title: Bogotá R Users Group: Manejo de datos faltantes en R: teoría, práctica y recomendaciones  [Virtual] , Colombia, Latin America
description:
En ciencias naturales, ciencias sociales, ciencias de la salud e ingenierías, por mencionar algunas áreas del conocimiento, la presencia de datos faltantes es relativamente frecuente. Esto ocurre debido a diferentes situaciones, por ejemplo, cierta información no es registrada por el experimentador, uno o más animales fallecen durante el experimento, o algunos sujetos entrevistados no responden una o varias preguntas de una encuesta. Generalmente los métodos para tratar correctamente los datos faltantes son subestimados, afectando así los resultados y las conclusiones del experimento.

En esta charla se explicará el fundamento teórico detrás de la pérdida de datos, así como las mejores técnicas de estimación. Además, se presentará una propuesta de paquete de R para el tratamiento de datos faltantes.

Nivel: Intermedio

Biografía
David Gutiérrez tiene 21 años y es estudiante de Biología de la Universidad de Caldas, tiene dos pasiones: la botánica y la estadística. Y desde la programación ha visto una oportunidad para potenciar el desarrollo de ambas ramas. En la botánica con el desarrollo de bases de datos taxonómicas y análisis bioinformático, y en la estadística desde el desarrollo de algoritmos que solucionan problemas comunes en la ciencia, como son los datos faltantes.

Paquetes para instalar:

## Instalar paquetes de visualización de datos faltantes
install.packages("visdat")
install.packages("VIM")

## Instalar paquete en desarrollo de estimación de datos faltantes
# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("davidbiol/empire")

Link inscripción zoom: https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_5rRgIAamQUGmIzigNGNJdQ

title: R-Ladies CDMX: Programadoras Mexicanas: Segundo Encuentro Anual R-Ladies México  [Virtual] , Mexico, Latin America
description:
A mediados de 2017 fue el primer encuentro de R-LadiesCDMX, el primer capítulo local en México de la organización mundial que busca cerrar la brecha de género en el lenguaje de programación de R.
Sólo cuatro años después somos más de 7,000 integrantes en 12 ciudades a lo largo de todo el país.
Creemos que la diversidad de género es muy importante en la comunidad de R y es por eso que por segundo año consecutivo volvemos a unir fuerzas y estrechamos lazos, reuniendo a las/los/les integrantes de R-Ladies en México en nuestro Segundo Encuentro Anual.

El objetivo de este año se enfoca en la visibilización de mujeres programadoras. A través de una sesión intensiva, esperamos mostrar y aplaudir el trabajo de diversas mujeres en R como desarrolladoras de paquetes dentro de la comunidad.

Sin embargo, también sabemos que estamos en crecimiento y el nivel de los usos de R varían. Por esto, estamos diseñando un programa en el que puedan participar aquellas personas que se integran de manera reciente al mundo de R. De esta manera, se podrá generar una comunidad R en México más diversa, donde se busca dar voz a aquellas personas con falta de representación y el apoyo colaborativo persista como la regla más que la excepción.

Objetivos

- Compartir experiencias y retos enfrentados.
- Escuchar la experiencia de mujeres en el desarrollo de paquetes de R.
- Empoderar a más mujeres para crear nuevos capítulos.
- Unir fuerzas para generar conferencias y talleres conjuntos que hagan crecer aún más la comunidad de usuarias y usuarios de R.

Programa

5:00-5:10 pm: ¿Quiénes somos? R-Ladies México
5:10-6:10 pm: Talleres:
Visualización de Datos en R
Desarrollo de Paquetes en R
6:10-6:20: Toma de Foto y Break
6:20-7:05: Tallerista principal
7:05-7:50: Tallerista principal
7:50-8:10 pm: ¿Cómo abrir un capítulo de R en mi ciudad?
8:10-8:40: Evento Social & Trivia

title: R-Ladies New York: R-Ladies NYC Lightning Talks (Prep and Submission Workshop)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
We are excited to host an online version of one our most popular events this fall - R-Ladies NYC Lightning Talks! We are extending the submission deadline, and are holding this workshop to provide guidance and support for interested speakers. If you are interested in proposing a talk but want to brainstorm ideas, get feedback, or some encouragement, join us!

Lighting talks are five minute talks. You can talk about anything R, Tech, and/or Data Science related. Looking for ideas? How about talking about a cool package you found, how you use R in your company, a favorite learning resource, your journey into Data Science, or a side project you've been working on?

We would especially love to hear from people who've never presented at a meetup or conference before and/or those who still don't feel confident speaking publicly. A lightning talk can be a great way to start out speaking, as it's quick, low-prep, and fun!

To celebrate the diversity in the R Community, we're prioritizing presenters who identify as a minority gender (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).

Revised Important Dates
Submissions due: Friday 10/1
Notification of acceptance: Sunday 10/4
Accepted speakers confirm participation: Wednesday 10/6
Slides due to us: Sunday 10/17
Lightning Talk Event: 10/19

title: R-Ladies Queretaro: Programadoras Mexicanas: Segundo Encuentro Anual R-Ladies México  [Virtual] , Mexico, Latin America
description:
A mediados de 2017 fue el primer encuentro de R-LadiesCDMX, el primer capítulo local en México de la organización mundial que busca cerrar la brecha de género en el lenguaje de programación de R.
Sólo cuatro años después somos más de 7,000 integrantes en 12 ciudades a lo largo de todo el país.
Creemos que la diversidad de género es muy importante en la comunidad de R y es por eso que por segundo año consecutivo volvemos a unir fuerzas y estrechamos lazos, reuniendo a las/los/les integrantes de R-Ladies en México en nuestro Segundo Encuentro Anual.

El objetivo de este año se enfoca en la visibilización de mujeres programadoras. A través de una sesión intensiva, esperamos mostrar y aplaudir el trabajo de diversas mujeres en R como desarrolladoras de paquetes dentro de la comunidad.

Sin embargo, también sabemos que estamos en crecimiento y el nivel de los usos de R varían. Por esto, estamos diseñando un programa en el que puedan participar aquellas personas que se integran de manera reciente al mundo de R. De esta manera, se podrá generar una comunidad R en México más diversa, donde se busca dar voz a aquellas personas con falta de representación y el apoyo colaborativo persista como la regla más que la excepción.

Objetivos

- Compartir experiencias y retos enfrentados.
- Escuchar la experiencia de mujeres en el desarrollo de paquetes de R.
- Empoderar a más mujeres para crear nuevos capítulos.
- Unir fuerzas para generar conferencias y talleres conjuntos que hagan crecer aún más la comunidad de usuarias y usuarios de R.

Programa

5:00-5:10 pm: ¿Quiénes somos? R-Ladies México
5:10-6:10 pm: Talleres:
Visualización de Datos en R
Desarrollo de Paquetes en R
6:10-6:20: Toma de Foto y Break
6:20-7:05: Tallerista principal
7:05-7:50: Tallerista principal
7:50-8:10 pm: ¿Cómo abrir un capítulo de R en mi ciudad?
8:10-8:40: Evento Social & Trivia

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Santa Barbara R Users Group: Fast-R: Improving the reproducibility and efficiency of your coding  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
https://afilazzola.github.io/SBMeetup2021-FastR/

General Information

With the wide-spread adoption of R for data management and analysis, there is huge potential for improving the efficiency of processing data. However, there is a significant learning curve with R that inhibits our ability to learn faster methods. Repetitive tasks in spreadsheets or even in R itself can often be revised to be faster, use less code, and have a simpler output One of the more appealing aspects of other programming languages for data science (Python, C++, SQL) relative to R is the speed that they can execute tasks. However, R has the capacity to function as fast, or better, than some of these other languages with some additional parametrization. This workshop will explore the power of “for” loops and parallel computing. These tools, while on the surface may appear intimidating, can be learned quickly with an exceptional payoff in time-saving efficiency. Using a combination of lecture and hands-on activities, this workshop will familiarize yourself with the tools necessary for improving your relationship with R and saving you time. A basic understanding of R is recommended because it will make the content more relevant and understandable. There is no prior knowledge necessarily for parallel computing or programming. Participants should bring a laptop with R already install using Mac, Linux, or Windows operating system (not a tablet, Chromebook, etc.).

Who: The course is aimed at R beginners or experienced analysts.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] The State of Distributed Computing, Canada, US/Canada
description:
REGISTER HERE FOR FREE: https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/2616299249952/WN_sgBQBKh6Ts2IuZBrAXZchg

There is an explosion of interest in distributed computing, fueled by exponential growth in data volumes, and promising new computational algorithms that routinely require thousands of cores. For many years now, Dask has been quietly transforming how the Python open-source ecosystem approaches distributed computing, and its adoption is entering a phase of rapid growth.

Join Anaconda Co-Founder and CEO, Peter Wang, and Coiled CEO and Dask Initial Author, Matthew Rocklin, on Tuesday, September 28, for a lively discussion about the state of distributed computing, including trends, pain points, and what's next on the horizon!

REGISTER HERE FOR FREE: https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/2616299249952/WN_sgBQBKh6Ts2IuZBrAXZchg

Join the NLP Summit: two weeks of immersive, industry-focused content. Week one will include 50+ unique sessions, with a special track on NLP in Healthcare. Week two will feature beginner to advanced training workshops with certifications.

You'll hear from teams who are leading the NLP space at NASA, HP, Zillow, Merck, Amazon, Stanford, Microsoft Research, Bank of America, Booz Allen Hamilton, Morgan Stanley, Roku Voice, Zillow and many more!

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: A UseR’s Introduction to Machine Learning in AWS   [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our October Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

“The cloud” can be intimidating, but with a few packages you can get up and running with a deep learning model on a giant computer in no time. In this talk, I’ll introduce one tool for doing ML in the cloud, AWS SageMaker. We’ll walk through all the code and tools needed to make an image classification algorithm on one of the toughest problems of our time: predicting what rating a dog’s photo will get from WeRateDogs (@dog_rates). No background in deep learning, image classification, or working in the cloud needed!

Emily Robinson is a Senior Data Scientist at Warby Parker, where she works on a centralized team tackling some of the company's biggest projects. Previously she worked at DataCamp, where she built and ran their experimentation analytics system, and at Etsy, where she worked with their search team. With Jacqueline Nolis, she is the author of Build a Career in Data Science, a guide to all the non-technical skills and knowledge you need to get a job in data science:
http://datascicareer.com/

title: Oslo useR! Group: [Bayes@Lund] {stantargets} and Target Markdown for Bayesian Model Validation  [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
>> This event is organized by our friends at the SkåneR useR! Group
>> https://www.meetup.com/Skane-R-User-Group/events/280641609/
>> We're excited to co-host the event together with them :)
>> We hope you'll enjoy this pan-Scandinavian event!

[Abstract]
The {targets} R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian statistics, and statistical genomics. Recent breakthroughs in the targets ecosystem make it easy to create ambitious, domain-specific, reproducible data analysis pipelines. Two highlights include {stantargets}, a new rOpenSci package that generates specialized workflows for Stan models while reducing the required volume of user-side R code, and Target Markdown, an R Markdown interface to transparently communicate the entire process of pipeline construction and prototyping. The example Target Markdown report at https://wlandau.github.io/rmedicine2021-pipeline (source: https://github.com/wlandau/rmedicine2021-pipeline) demonstrates both capabilities in a simulation-based workflow to validate a Bayesian longitudinal linear model common in clinical trial data analysis.

[Bio]
Will Landau is a statistician and software developer in the life sciences industry. He specializes in the computational aspects of Bayesian statistics and reproducible research, and is the creator and maintainer of the {targets} and {drake} R packages.

[Note]
This event is part of Bayes@Lund workshop series, co-organized with SkåneR useR! Group.

title: CalgaryR: Using R for Geographic Information System (GIS) and Landscape Analyses  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our next speaker - Danielle Clake will share her work on bumble bees and landscape fragmentation using R.

The loss of habitat is a well-known challenge facing global biodiversity, but we still require a better understanding of how specific aspects of landscape changes can affect communities. For example, while the amount of habitat available to a species is known to be important for its survival, there can also be an influence of the configuration of that habitat into one or many patches, or of the patches into either simple or complex shapes. Different landscape metrics have been developed to characterize these and other differences between habitats. R provides useful tools to calculate and assess landscape metrics, and to integrate the results into downstream analysis and modelling.

In this talk, Danielle will provide a brief overview of the basics of spatial data and geographic information system (GIS) analysis in R, using the sf and raster packages to create and visualize spatial data. She will then show how the landscapemetrics package can be used to characterize the composition and configuration of landscapes.

Her research on bumble bee (Bombus sp.) habitat in the Rocky Mountains is an example of how these types of landscape analyses can be applied to test hypotheses about the relationships between species and the landscapes that they inhabit. Danielle will discuss her findings in this project, and the various uses of R throughout.

title: R-Ladies Bariloche: GRUPO 1. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"  [Virtual] , Argentina, Latin America
description:
¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versión traducida al español de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes más!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ ¡Está muy bueno!

• Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 días para avanzar con la lectura y comprensión del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro será guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

• En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo número 3 “visualización de datos” (¡Qué bueno, empezamos con gráficos con ggplot2 ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reunión con el capítulo previamente leído y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducción del libro aún: adelante, es corta, y les dará un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reunión de organización vimos un panorama de la introducción.

• En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. ¡ATENCIÓN! ¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÁS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO DE LUNES DE 9 A 11 AM.

• ¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sólo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrónico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

• Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aún no se sumaron, van a recibir más adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que será nuestra principal vía de comunicación. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escríbannos y les damos una orientación rápida.

• Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capítulo número 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo [masked]. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

• A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionará. Por ejemplo, sorteará o decidirá quién guiará el siguiente capítulo, si verán un capítulo, medio capítulo o dos capítulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarán lo que se vió en el capítulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir información en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el código de conducta que encontrarán en la página.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos básicos de R.

¡ATENCIÓN! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reunión se enviará unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estén alertas al correo.

¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versión traducida al español de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes más!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ ¡Está muy bueno!

• Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 días para avanzar con la lectura y comprensión del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro será guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

• En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo número 3 “visualización de datos” (¡Qué bueno, empezamos con gráficos con ggplot2 ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reunión con el capítulo previamente leído y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducción del libro aún: adelante, es corta, y les dará un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reunión de organización vimos un panorama de la introducción.

• En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. ¡ATENCIÓN! ¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÁS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO DE LUNES DE 9 A 11 AM.

• ¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sólo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrónico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

• Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aún no se sumaron, van a recibir más adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que será nuestra principal vía de comunicación. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escríbannos y les damos una orientación rápida.

• Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capítulo número 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo [masked]. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

• A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionará. Por ejemplo, sorteará o decidirá quién guiará el siguiente capítulo, si verán un capítulo, medio capítulo o dos capítulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarán lo que se vió en el capítulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir información en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el código de conducta que encontrarán en la página.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos básicos de R.

¡ATENCIÓN! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reunión se enviará unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estén alertas al correo.

title: Vienna<-R: Data Science Conference Austria 2021, Austria, Europe
description:
Dear ViennaR Community!

We're glad to invite you to the upcoming Data Science Conference Austria - a free hybrid event dedicated to AI-powered sustainability!

Make sure to book your seat at https://austria.datasciconference.com/ticket for the 2-day event:

Sept 27: Tech tutorials covering interesting data science use cases and languages (R, Python, Julia) to improve sustainability, see schedule here: https://austria.datasciconference.com/schedule/tutorials.html

Sept 28: Talks about data & sustainability topics. The schedule will be filled in the upcoming days. See here an overview of our amazing speakers: https://austria.datasciconference.com.

Let's save the world through data!

See you there,
Mario

PS: Note that the free pass is for virtual attendance only! A selected group of people will be invited to Talent Garden on Sept 28 for the Data & AI Summit.

title: R-Ladies Santiago: Club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (sesión 4)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
El próximo jueves 30 de septiembre nos reuniremos para nuestra cuarta sesión del club de lectura sobre libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

- ¿Cómo funciona el club de lectura?
Dividiremos la lectura del libro en seis sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un capítulo del libro. Cada sesión la liderará alguien de nuestra comunidad.
Esta cuarta sesión estará a cargo de Francesca Rosales (https://www.linkedin.com/in/francesca-danae-rosales-rojas-314457b6/), cientista política y estudiante del magíster en Pensamiento Contemporáneo. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 4, "4. "What Gets Counted Counts", en el que se presenta el cuarto principio del feminismo de datos: repensar los binarismos y las jerarquías.

- ¿Qué pasa si no puedo leer en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. El día del taller compartiremos la contraseña en los comentarios del evento.

- HORA
El evento se realizará a las 17:00 horas de la zona horaria UTC-3. Puedes revisar a qué hora corresponde en tu zona en el siguiente enlace: https://everytimezone.com/s/7ac3db47

title: R-Ladies Philly: Bayes Rules! An Introduction to Bayesian Modeling with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Bayesian statistics?! Once an obscure term, this alternative to the more ingrained frequentist philosophy is having a moment (a long one). In this workshop, we’ll explore some core principles of the Bayesian philosophy, learn to think like Bayesians, and get our hands on some Bayesian models. The workshop materials will rely on the following R packages: tidyverse, bayesrules, bayesplot, rstan, rstanarm. The rstan package in particular would be great to install in advance and works best with R version 4.0.0 or later.

About Speaker

Alicia Johnson is an associate professor of statistics at Macalester College in St Paul, Minnesota. Her research interests span Bayesian statistics, computational statistics, and statistics / data science education. Outside of statistics, she enjoys building things, snow (during the appropriate months), and vitamin D among other things.

title: R-Ladies Montevideo: ¡Por favor... Dibújame un proyecto!  [Virtual] , Uruguay, Latin America
description:
Felices de tener un nuevo encuentro virtual con una invitada de lujo como es Maëlle Salmon.

Resumen de la charla:

Tener organizados tus proyectos de R es útil aunque no tengas colaboradores tan exigentes como El Principito.
¿Pero cómo se logra?
¿Se pone el proyecto en algún tipo de caja?
En esta charla presentaré algunas herramientas útiles: git, here, renv, targets, orderly...
También explicaré si transformar todo en un paquete de R siempre es una buena idea.
Después de mi charla habrás oído consejos y trucos para tus proyectos en R.
¡Espero que cad@ un@ aprenda al menos una cosa nueva!

title: R-Ladies Miami: Tune xgboost with {tidymodels} 👩🏽‍💻  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Description: The tidymodels framework is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. In this meetup, we will walk through a case study from SLICED (the competitive data science streaming show) on predicting Airbnb prices in NYC, and use hands-on live coding to learn how to use tidymodels to tune xgboost models. Come with your questions as we interactively code together and learn about topics like regression modeling, resampling, and model evaluation!

Bio: Julia Silge is a data scientist and software engineer at RStudio PBC where she works on open source modeling tools. She is an author, an international keynote speaker, and a real-world practitioner focusing on data analysis and machine learning practice. Julia loves text analysis, making beautiful charts, and communicating about technical topics with diverse audiences.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we’ll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you’re still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Valparaíso: Club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (sesión 4)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
El próximo jueves 30 de septiembre nos reuniremos para nuestra cuarta sesión del club de lectura sobre libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

- ¿Cómo funciona el club de lectura?
Dividiremos la lectura del libro en seis sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un capítulo del libro. Cada sesión la liderará alguien de nuestra comunidad.
Esta cuarta sesión estará a cargo de Francesca Rosales (https://www.linkedin.com/in/francesca-danae-rosales-rojas-314457b6/), cientista política y estudiante del magíster en Pensamiento Contemporáneo. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 4, "4. “What Gets Counted Counts", en el que se presenta el cuarto principio del feminismo de datos: repensar los binarismos y las jerarquías.

- ¿Qué pasa si no puedo leer en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. El día del taller compartiremos la contraseña en los comentarios del evento.

- HORA
El evento se realizará a las 17:00 horas de la zona horaria UTC-3. Puedes revisar a qué hora corresponde en tu zona en el siguiente enlace: https://everytimezone.com/s/7ac3db47
